text:
The next data is
publication data.

Rob, can you tell us a bit
about the publication data?

So this data was
looking at publication

of papers that were
describing clinical trials.

The outcome is timed
until publication.

And what's a particular
interest is whether or not

if the study had a
positive-- the trial had

a positive result
versus a null result.

Whether that led to
faster publication,

as one might think
that's the case.
Or publication at all.
Or publication at all.
Yeah.

The time until
publication was at

linked into to the
positivity of the trial.
And so censoring.

If the time is censored, it
means never was published.

Never was published or
I think maybe the study
ended before the publication.

I mean, at the end of
the data collection,
the paper was still unpublished.

So I guess this
speaks to the bias

in published clinical trials
and medical papers, right?

It is trying to examine
whether there is such a bias.
Right.

The incantation is
pretty much the same.
We've got time and status.

The status variable here is
whether or not it was published.

In this case, publication
date is the endpoint.

It's a positive result.
It's a positive outcome
if it's published.

Posres raises whether the
result in the study was positive
or not.

And that's the binary
predictor in this case.

And we produce a
Kaplan-Meier curve for that,

stratified by
negative or positive.
And sure enough, it looks--

well, the curves
are pretty close,

but it looks like down at
the bottom here at least,

that if it was a
negative result,

it tended not to get published
in the slightly longer time
to ever or never publication.

Whereas if the
result was positive,

it seemed to be a
little bit ahead.

Some of those papers
waited a long time.
Didn't they?
They waited a long time.
Yeah.

Looks like the median is
around two years maybe.
Oh My goodness.
Yeah.
Are these statistics journals?
[LAUGHTER]
No.

Statistics journal
aren't that bad.

That's, that's a very long time,
especially for medical journals.

So now, we'll fit
the same model using

a Cox's proportional hazards
model and we'll do a test.

We don't do the
log-rank test here.

But we just use the Cox's model
test for this binary variable.

And we see the p-value
is not significant.

So in fact, it's not
significant, the difference.

And the log-rank test will
provide a similar conclusion.

And here we do
the log-rank test.

And once again, if we put in
other predictors in the model--

we're going to put all
the other predictors

in the model except the
funding mechanism variable.
Why was that left out?
I don't remember.
[LAUGHTER]
Sorry, I asked.
[LAUGHTER]

In the actual lab, in the book,
I believe it's done both ways,
but--
It's done both ways.
Yeah.

So here we see there's a
few significant variables.
There's the impact.

That's the impact
of the journal.
Impact factor.
Yeah.
Yeah.
And that's significant.

And this is whether it was
a clinical endpoint or not.
Right.
That's significant.

And then of course,
positive result

is now significant
in the presence
of these other variables.
So that's curious.
And this often happens.

There's often confounding
and masking in data.

And when you put in
other factors, then

the strength of a predictor
can actually come out.
And that's what's happened here.

And we left with a number
of important predictors.

So the trial again, focused on a
clinical endpoint and the impact

of the study, and whether the
study has a positive or negative

result. I see it was the impact
of the study, not the journal.
